block.p: Israelis Credit Barak As Violence Abates The morning after Palestinian rioting disintegrated into fierce gunfire, many Israeli and even some Palestinian political analysts were surprised to find themselves crediting Prime Minister Ehud Barak with defusing the crisis. The gun battles between Israeli and Palestinian forces had ended by morning, although low-level clashes continued.

Israelis Credit Barak As Violence Abates The morning after Palestinian rioting disintegrated into fierce gunfire, many Israeli and even some Palestinian political analysts were surprised to find themselves crediting Prime Minister Ehud Barak with defusing the crisis. The gun battles between Israeli and Palestinian forces had ended by morning, although low-level clashes continued.
Arabs gave a martyr's burial to a 20-year-old Palestinian policeman who was killed on Monday during an exchange of gunfire with Israelis.

U.S. Opposes Iran Loans The Clinton administration will oppose the first World Bank loans offered to Iran in seven years, even though Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright declared some easing of sanctions recently, officials said.

Bid to Improve Peacekeeping The American ambassador to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke, called for an overhaul of peacekeeping operations and for more money from member nations to make the operations effective. Some diplomats, while agreeing change is needed, said the United States was partly responsible for the problem.
Bush Opposes Kosovo Deadline Gov. George W. Bush criticized a bill backed by fellow Republicans in the Senate that would set a deadline for withdrawing American ground troops from Kosovo.

Zimbabwe Agrees to Monitors President Robert Mugabe agreed to let Commonwealth observers monitor a parliamentary election he called for June 24 and 25, according to the Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon.
Ethiopia Military Drive Ethiopia has taken control of a now empty town that once belonged to Eritrea as part of what appeared to be a successful drive into Eritrea in the latest flare-up of fighting.

Labor Unrest in China Nearly 2,000 workers owed back pay, joined by retirees owed pensions, have besieged a factory and government offices in the northeastern city of Liaoyang, in the latest example of growing labor unrest as once-dominant state industries collapse.

Dominican Republic Elections Dominicans turned out in large numbers in a multicandidate presidential election. No candidate is expected to win a majority, but early this morning preliminary results based on 27.7 percent of the polling places were giving 49 percent of the vote to Hipolito Mejia of the left-leaning Dominican Revolutionary Party.

Mexican Candidate Gets Help Vicente Fox Quesada, the opposition candidate who appears to have a narrow lead in the presidential race, got a public relations boost from two prominent Mexicans with family roots in the governing party.

E.P.A. to Issue Rules To Curb Diesel Pollution The E.P.A. plans to announce new pollution-control rules that will cut truck and bus emissions drastically, in part through a 97 percent reduction in the sulfur content of diesel fuel over the next 10 years. The oil industry opposes the rules, saying diesel fuel prices will rise.
Wresting a Vote on Gun Control Democrats used procedural maneuvers to bring the Senate to a halt until Republican leaders promised to allow votes on two gun control measures today.

Move to Repeal Phone Tax A House subcommittee held a hearing that was expected to begin the process of repealing a 102-year-old ''luxury'' tax on telephones that was passed to help finance the Spanish American War. The 3 percent tax now costs the average household $50 a year; its repeal would cost the government $5 billion a year.

Social Security Plan Assailed Vice President Al Gore asserted that Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to let workers invest some of their Social Security taxes would hurt the very baby boomers it is supposed to help by putting retirement savings at the mercy of the markets.

Last Radio Calls Before Crash The government made public a transcript of conversations between air controllers and the crew of Egyptair Flight 990, which crashed in the Atlantic on Oct. 31, killing all 217 people aboard. The transcript showed only routine communications. The cockpit voice recorder transcript is expected to be made public this summer.

Investigating New Mexico Fire State and federal officials began an inquiry into why the Park Service started the fire to clear underbrush near Los Alamos despite weather forecasts that would make the fire hard to control. Thousands of residents returned to Los Alamos.
Better Child Care in Military A private study said the military had so improved its child care system that it should serve as a model for state and national programs.

A Washington Fixture Departs Helen Thomas, 79, a White House reporter since John F. Kennedy was president, resigned from U.P.I. a day after the news service was acquired by the company that publishes The Washington Times.
3M Environmental Concerns The giant consumer products company said it would stop making many of its Scotchgard products after tests showed chemical compounds linger in the environment for years.

A Death in Antarctica An Australian astrophysicist died suddenly of undetermined causes on Friday at a research center operated by the National Science Foundation, and his body must remain there until the Southern winter ends in October. It was only the third death at the pole in nearly 35 years.

Mrs. Clinton Is Nominated, To Face Unknown Opponent The New York State Democratic Party nominated Hillary Rodham Clinton as its candidate for senator. In her acceptance speech, in Albany, she portrayed the campaign as a contest between political philosophies, an attack not on any candidate but on Republican policies that aides said would stand whether her opponent ended up being Mayor Giuliani or some other Republican.
Mr. Giuliani met with doctors about his prostate cancer and gave no indication of his political plans.

New Jersey Senate Debate Jon S. Corzine and Jim Florio clashed on gun control, national security and taxes, with each of the Democrats trying to portray himself as the stronger champion of the elderly and working families.

Order to Curtail Pollution Gov. John G. Rowland plans to sign an executive order today that is intended to sharply cut emissions from Connecticut's six antiquated coal- and oil-burning power plants and dozens of other plants within three years, joining New York and Massachusetts in moving to curb pollution that causes acid rain and smog.

Vallone Plan to Monitor Police City Council Speaker Peter Vallone renewed his call for a city-sponsored police watchdog panel, which he said would discourage federal intervention in local police affairs.
Effort on Patronage Opposed An association of city judges opposes an effort by the state's chief administrative judge to curtail political patronage in the court system.

Levy Wins Mayor's Support Mayor Giuliani said he would support the appointment of Harold O. Levy as chancellor of city schools, virtually assuring his choice by the Board of Education at its meeting today.

Artist Sues Gallery Al Hirschfeld, 96, the renowned caricaturist, has taken his longtime dealer, Margo Feiden, and her gallery to court to try to end their contract, saying he had been cheated and should regain control of his work.
Flyers Pull Even With Devils Philadelphia beat the Devils, 4-3, to tie the four-of-seven-game Eastern finals at a game apiece.
Karl Shapiro The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet was 86 years old.

Interest Rates Increased The Federal Reserve adopted a more aggressive approach to fighting inflation, pushing short-term interest rates up by half a percentage point to try to slow the headlong pace of economic growth. The Fed also signaled that there might well be more rises to come.

Consumers will quickly begin to feel the pinch as borrowing -- from home equity loans to car and truck financing to credit cards -- becomes more expensive. Rates on fixed-rate mortgages, however, have already climbed and may even retreat some from their current level of about 8.5 percent, specialists said.
Consumer prices were unchanged in April and new home construction rose, government figures showed, signaling the economy was expanding with little to no inflation.

Investors widely expected the rate increase. The Dow rose 126.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,934.57; the Nasdaq climbed 109.92 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,717.57; and the S.& P. 500 jumped 13.68 points, to 1,466.04.

Coke Shares Decline Coca-Cola's largest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, said it would not meet its growth target in the United States this year and was facing even bigger hurdles in Britain. Shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises tumbled 30 percent, or $6.9375, to $15.625, a 52-week low, and shares of Coca-Cola fell $3, to $48.9375.
Editorials: Mrs. Clinton's moment; behind the rate hike; imitations of ''West Wing''; a promising accord in Montana. Columns: Maureen Dowd, Paul Krugman.
